As I lay in bed, half-asleep, my mother's voice pierced through the darkness, calling my name at around eight in the morning. I groggily opened my eyes, trying to make sense of the time, but it was still dark, and I couldn't see anything. I was disoriented and confused, unsure of what time it was or what day it was. My mother's voice was the only thing I could hear, echoing in the darkness, telling me something about the weather in Calcutta. It had been raining for three days, she said, and I felt a wave of exhaustion wash over me. I lay there for a few moments, trying to shake off the sleep and make sense of the situation. Despite the confusion, it was a nice morning, with a gentle drizzle falling from the sky.

Last night in class, we discussed the assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World," by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores the concept of "implacement" and the second, "displacement." Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the central organizing principle, with a focus on the finite nature of time and the need to make the most of it. He contends that placing place at the center of culture can foster a more grounded community. So far, this book has been the most engaging read of the semester.

Fall 1974: I was attempting to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book for the 13th time. I was not then nor am I now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So, as I struggled to make sense out of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as I was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that, my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and, just as before, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.

I found the idea of flag-burning as a way out of being ostracized as a witch intriguing. As a non-American blogger, I've been hesitant to join the debate, particularly regarding flag-burning, but since I've started writing about it (the topic, not the act), I might as well say something. Firstly, I believe that having a law against flag-burning is utterly nonsensical. When you grant a symbol automatic reverence and protection, you're taking a small but significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are fleeting and subjective; their meaning is derived from how they are perceived, not inherently from their physical form. Burning a flag may be seen as a form of protest or a way to express disdain, but it is not a violent act. It is a constitutionally protected form of free speech, and as such, it should be respected.

Hill co-wrote the film with John Carpenter, who directed the movie and also starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. The movie made over $60 million worldwide, a record for an independent film at the time of its release.

Hill began her career in the film industry as a production assistant and worked her way up to become an assistant director and second-unit director before collaborating with Carpenter on several projects, including Escape from New York and The Fog. She was regarded as a pioneering woman in the industry, taking on roles that were traditionally held by men in the 1970s.

Hill's legacy in the film industry is undeniable, and her work on Halloween has become a cult classic. Her passing is a loss for the industry and her fans, but her contributions will continue to be celebrated and remembered.

Yukos is a US-based oil and gas company that is facing financial difficulties and is currently in the process of being broken up by Russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (¬£14bn) tax bill. The company has filed for bankruptcy in the US in an attempt to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos' lawyers now claim that the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.

Online reviews aid customer decision-making, but spamming tactics can manipulate them. Sophisticated spammers adapt quickly, using various strategies that evade detection. Existing detectors prioritize accuracy, but this approach undermines trust in product evaluations. To address this, we develop a game-theoretic approach that pits spammers and detectors against each other, with each side seeking to outmaneuver the other. This leads to stable detectors that are resilient to diverse spamming tactics.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. We use the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses exhibit superior robustness to Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we investigate the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with an arbitrary number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share the same form of structure, which involves fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results hold for the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition and are valid for both over- and under-specified models. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results regarding the scaling with the separation between the components.

The first, Berglund-H\"ubsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $g^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions."

We present a novel mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems that resolves close encounters with unprecedented accuracy. Our method combines a high-order mvs scheme with a time regularization technique, enabling the preservation of stability properties while reducing the effective step size during close encounters. We demonstrate the algorithm's ability to resolve almost exact collisions while maintaining the same time step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. Our long-term simulations of systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr showcase the algorithm's accuracy and efficiency, outperforming hybrid methods such as Mercury in terms of energy conservation.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is entanglement witness, which measures the witness operator and is guaranteed to be positive for separable states and can be negative for entangled states. In reality, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert space dimension with respect to the system size, it is challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. As a comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

In general relativity, the unique stationary solution is the Kerr spacetime with a distinct multipolar structure depending on mass and spin. We develop a method to extract multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter have a richer multipolar structure, which provides a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that multipole moments are typically larger than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin.

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression is an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as Euclid or LSST. In this first paper in a series of two, we use simulations to build a Euclid-like tomographic mock data set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). In addition, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard ŒªCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

The authors propose an open-source neural network model for classifying audio segments into one of four categories: (1) vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, (2) vocalizations produced by other children, (3) adult male speech, and (4) adult female speech. The proposed model could be useful for language acquisition studies that aim to quantify the quantity and quality of speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving speech development.
To develop the model, the authors gathered a diverse corpus of child-centered recordings, which adds up to a total of 260 hours of recordings and covers 10 languages. The corpus includes recordings of children aged 2-6 years old, with a mix of different languages and speaking styles. The authors plan to make the model and the corpus open-source, to allow other researchers to use and build upon their work.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between standard model and higher dimension operators, which parameterize the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes impose an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension six operators, resulting in the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution cancelling. In this case, measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable, which is generated only by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can exhibit unconventional superconductivity at high critical temperatures is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. We demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity, v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been shown to be a powerful and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic material, and this approach has been applied in a variety of applications. Notably, it allows for grading the voltage drop across high voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without the risk of surface flashover. However, a concern with this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is prone to oxidation. In this study, we investigate the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. Our results indicate that, following an initial decrease of up to 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity of the surface of the alumina shows a slow decrease of about 10% over the subsequent year.

We propose a novel skyrmion-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, based on the idea of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the Skyrme charge for any smooth configuration. In addition, singular configurations can be identified as $n_f=1$ baryons charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, vector mesons play the role of Chern-Simons vector fields living on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the $n_f=1$ baryon. We propose that this current is the effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified picture for the two types of baryons and allows them to continuously transform one into the other in a natural way. Furthermore, Chern-Simons duality on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in junctions combines anomalous Hall and Josephson physics. We study how superposition impacts transport properties. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling creates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula to evaluate transverse current components, showing that their amplitudes are widely adjustable by spin-orbit coupling strengths or superconducting phase difference.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven an indispensable tool for designing efficient quantum algorithms. In this article, we improve upper bounds for quantum hitting times, which determine the time required for a quantum walk to find a target with high probability. Specifically, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, reducing the hitting time upper bound from $n^5$ to $n^2\log n$. Our methods also improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk algorithm for finding a marked node on an ergodic, reversible Markov chain, from $n^5$ to $n\log n$.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (emris) can be classified as dry or wet emris based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or loss-cone) emris, previously thought to be the main source of emris for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative emri formation channel: wet emri formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, boosting the formation rate of emris in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about him/her, i.e., no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Despite this lack of information, we still expect our recommender systems to attract the users at first glance, so that they decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem belongs to the new user cold-start category, and it is crucial to the development and survival of a company. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, such as setting up an interview process, or make use of side information [10] like user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to provide this extra effort, and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.

Deep learning solves problems unreachable for heuristic algorithms. It has been applied to wireless communications, but current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While gains have been made by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the whole receiver. This often results in a nonlinear problem that is infeasible to implement. We propose a deep convolutional neural network, deeprx, that executes the whole receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant fashion. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) from which to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds often contains thousands of similar inputs, leading to wasted fuzzing effort. To address this, fuzzers use distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds that triggers the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we explore systematically. We present results of 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact in finding bugs in real-world software.

We investigate multi-agent systems with partial observation, where agents are divided into groups with isomorphic state transition structures. A scalable supervisor, designed for partial observation, is proposed, which does not need to be recomputed as the number of agents changes. Sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness are given for the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level, and an example is provided to illustrate the proposed synthesis.

Electric network frequency fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for enf estimation employs temporal windowing based on the filter-bank capon spectral estimator. A type of Gohrberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach utilizes a non-rectangular temporal window for spectral estimation, yielding improved results in both power recordings and speech recordings.

The direpack package aims to provide a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques as a single, consistent package in Python. The included methods are categorized into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided, including classical principal component regression and sparse partial robust M-regression. The package also includes a set of classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Direpack has been designed to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, allowing the estimators to seamlessly integrate into statistical and machine learning pipelines.

In this paper, the authors propose a new approach for conducting Bayesian inference for causal inference in survey data with random effects, which is a common problem in survey research where the relationship between the observed data and the causal parameters is not linear. The authors propose a weighted least squares approach that uses Bayesian methods to estimate the hyperparameters of the model, which are the parameters that control the distribution of the random effects. The authors show that their approach produces unbiased estimates of the hyperparameters and is consistent with the population distribution of the data, while other frequentist methods do not. They also demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach through simulations and a real-data example. The paper provides a valuable contribution to the field of survey research by bridging the gap between traditional survey estimation methods and Bayesian modeling, and demonstrates the advantages of using Bayesian methods for causal inference in survey research.

The eccentric debris rings around stars like Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, which assumes a circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$. In a minor variation of this scenario, narrower belts can form if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could arise from disc instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity without the need for any planets.

The history of the formation of the Milky Way galaxy is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the $GAIA$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced.

To do this, we combined the kinematic information provided by $GAIA$ for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion.

Our results show that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of intrinsic dimension is crucial for dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces 'intrinsic', an r package with novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators. The package includes three models: two-nn, gride, and hidalgo. These models are categorized into homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The functions for these two categories cover frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The hidalgo model is a Bayesian mixture model with an efficient Gibbs sampler.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics on a nanosecond scale, promising to power spintronic reservoir computing (rc) systems. Two physical rc systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (msm) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (stnos) were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system predictions. Micromagnetic simulations revealed that a single msm can achieve outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition, while a physical rc system consisting of 24 stnos can effectively solve complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems.

Ranking algorithms are crucial in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we reveal a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer items reporting a signal, the higher the collective traffic they attract. This phenomenon, known as the few-get-richer effect, emerges when there are few distinct classes of items and ranking is based on popularity. We demonstrate analytically and experimentally how the effect arises from people's tendency to click on top-ranked items and their diverse preferences for item classes. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the spread of misinformation.

Our framework seamlessly integrates pattern selection, pruning, and weight training, ensuring optimized execution on mobile platforms.

Sputnik was not the first piece of human technology to enter space, but it was the most significant. The V-2 rocket, used by Germany in missile attacks against allied cities during World War II, was actually developed by both the U.S. and U.S.S.R. after the war and used for their own projects.

Menstruation: A natural biological process that has been shrouded in secrecy and stigma for centuries. Despite being a universal experience, it's a topic that many of us whisper about, as if it's something to be ashamed of. In fact, more than 800 million women worldwide are menstruating right now, and yet, it remains a source of discomfort and embarrassment for many. From my perspective and that of the women around me, it's a draining experience, one that requires careful discretion and secrecy. We must carefully conceal our sanitary products, hiding them in brown paper bags and rushing to the bathroom to change in private. It's exhausting to maintain a facade of normalcy, pretending that the cramps and discomfort don't exist, while internally, we're struggling to manage the pain.

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere, but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
